Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[772, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 380, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 729, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[288, 87, 705, 306]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 875, 356]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = 5x^{\frac{3}{2}} - 20x\) and the line with equation \(y = x - 16\). The \(x\)-coordinates of the points of intersection of the curve and line are 1 and 16.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 631, 387]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region between the curve and the line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 368, 918, 387]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 139, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Find the first three terms, in ascending powers of \(x\), in the expansion of each of the following expressions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 117, 180, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 117, 267, 135]]<|/det|>
(2 \(-px)^{5}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 343, 180, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 336, 270, 361]]<|/det|>
\(\left(1 - \frac{1}{2} x\right)^{4}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 339, 920, 358]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 562, 146, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
Given that the coefficient of \(x^{2}\) in the expansion of \(\left(2 - px\right)^{5}\left(1 - \frac{1}{2} x\right)^{4}\) is 93, find the possible values of the constant \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is \(2x^{2} - kxy + 2 = 0\) and the equation of a line is \(y = px + 3\), where \(k\) and \(p\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 122, 144, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 121, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
Given that \(k = 2\) and \(p = 11\), find the coordinates of the points of intersection of the curve and the line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Given instead that \(p = 4\), find the set of values of \(k\) for which the curve and the line do not intersect.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 465, 102]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is \(y = 4x^{2} + \frac{9}{x^{2}} - 8.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 146, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
A point \(P\) is moving along the curve in such a way that its \(y\)-coordinate is decreasing at 5 units per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 737, 186]]<|/det|>
Find the rate at which the \(x\)-coordinate of point \(P\) is changing when \(x = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 165, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 811, 88]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary points of the curve and determine their nature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 915, 118]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 84, 660, 252]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 266, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector \(ABC\) of a circle with centre \(A\) and radius \(r\mathrm{cm}\). The angle \(BAC\) is \(\alpha\) radians, where \(0 < \alpha < \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 316, 146, 335]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 314, 888, 336]]<|/det|>
It is given that the area of the triangle \(ABC\) is \(4 \mathrm{cm}^2\) and the area of the sector \(ABC\) is \(8 \alpha \mathrm{cm}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 346, 489, 367]]<|/det|>
Find the exact area of the shaded segment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 348, 920, 367]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 403, 88]]<|/det|>
The functions f and g are defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 100, 628, 121]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f(x) = \sqrt{x}}\qquad \mathrm{for} x\geqslant 0,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 131, 635, 152]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g(x) = 3\sqrt{x + 2} - 5}\qquad \mathrm{for} x\geqslant -2.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 917, 198]]<|/det|>
Describe fully a sequence of transformations which transforms the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) to the graph of \(y = \mathrm{g}(x)\). You should make clear the order in which the transformations are applied. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 917, 228]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<form>......

<form>......

<form>......

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 580, 803, 848]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 860, 452, 878]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = \mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 891, 146, 909]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 890, 824, 909]]<|/det|>
On the diagram sketch the graph of \(y = \mathrm{g}^{-1}(x)\) together with any relevant mirror line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 892, 917, 910]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 395, 92]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 185, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 355, 336, 374]]<|/det|>
State the range of \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 374]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 448, 343, 467]]<|/det|>
The function h is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 477, 603, 497]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{h}(x) = x - 2\qquad \mathrm{for} x\geqslant 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 509, 144, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 509, 366, 528]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}\mathrm{h}(4)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 509, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 725, 144, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 725, 631, 744]]<|/det|>
Explain why the composite function \(\mathrm{h}\mathrm{g}^{-1}\) cannot be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 725, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
